ì €ë²ˆì£¼ íšŒì˜ì—ì„œ íŒ€ì¥ë‹˜ê³¼ ì°¨ì¥ë‹˜ì´ kafkaì— ëŒ€í•´ ì§§ê²Œ ì´ì•¼ê¸°ë¥¼ ë‚˜ëˆ„ì…¨ëŠ”ë° ë‚˜ëŠ” ë©”ì‹œì§€ ë‹¤ë£¨ëŠ” ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì¸ ì¤„ë§Œ ì•Œì•˜ëŠ”ë° ë¹„ë™ê¸°ë“± ë‹¤ì–‘í•œ ì´ì•¼ê¸°ë¥¼ í•´ì£¼ì…¨ë‹¤. ë†“ì¹ ìˆ˜ì—†ê¸°ì— ë”°ë¡œ ê³µë¶€ë¥¼ í•´ë³´ì•˜ë‹¤.

Kafka ì¹´í”„ì¹´

chatGPTì— ë¬¸ì˜í•˜ë‹ˆ ì•„ë˜ì™€ ê°™ì´ ë‹µë³€ì„ ì–»ì—ˆë‹¤.

Kafka is an open-source platform used for handling large amounts of data in real-time. It was originally developed by LinkedIn, but is now maintained by the Apache Software Foundation.
Think of Kafka as a messaging system that can receive, store, and distribute data streams. It allows you to publish data to a stream or subscribe to a stream to receive data. This makes it useful for applications where data needs to be processed and analyzed as itâ€™s generated, such as in a real-time analytics system.
Hereâ€™s a super easy example to help illustrate Kafkaâ€™s functionality:
Letâ€™s say you have a website where users can upload images. Whenever a new image is uploaded, you want to process it in some way (maybe resizing it or running some filters on it) and then store it on your servers. You also want to display a thumbnail of the image on the website so users can see it right away.
With Kafka, you could set up a â€œtopicâ€ (a stream of data) called â€œimage-uploadsâ€. Whenever a user uploads an image, your website would send a message to the â€œimage-uploadsâ€ topic with the details of the image (e.g. the file name, user ID, etc.). You could have a separate â€œconsumerâ€ application (i.e. a program that subscribes to the â€œimage-uploadsâ€ topic) that listens for new messages and processes them accordingly.
For example, the consumer application might download the image, resize it, and store it on your servers. It could also generate a thumbnail and send a message to a separate â€œthumbnailsâ€ topic with the details of the thumbnail. Another consumer application could listen for messages on the â€œthumbnailsâ€ topic and display the thumbnail on the website.
This is just one simple example, but hopefully it gives you an idea of how Kafka can be used to handle real-time data processing and distribution.
